thread.section_title: Politics - News, views, gossip, pictures, video - Mirror Online
thread.title: Labour and Tory MPs unite to launch EU exit campaign backed by millionaire donors
thread.title_full: Labour and Tory MPs unite to launch EU exit campaign backed by millionaire donors - Mirror Online

author: Ben Glaze
title: Labour and Tory MPs unite to launch EU exit campaign backed by millionaire donors
text:
The EU referendum battle has kicked off in earnest with the launch of the Vote Leave campaign.
MPs from across the political divide have joined forces with top businessmen to press for a UK exit.
David Cameron has pledged to hold an In/Out vote before the end of 2017.
A major poll carried out in the hours after his Tory conference speech suggests he faces an uphill struggle to convince people to stay in, unless he can guarantee UK law trumps EU rules.
An ICM survey of 1,947 people found 44% would vote to remain in the 28-member union, with 39% opting to leave and a crucial 17% undecided.
But 53% of the public would choose to leave unless the Prime Minister can strike a new Brussels deal, ending the supremacy of EU law in the UK.
Mr Cameron welcomes Estonian Prime Minister Taavi Roivas to Downing Street today, before hosting German Chancellor Angela Merkel at Chequers tonight.
REUTERS Not too close: David Cameron is meeting Angela Merkel at his country retreat of Chequers
The face-to-face meetings with the two EU leaders are the latest round of talks in the PM’s faltering bid to renegotiate Britain’s relationship with Europe.
Eurosceptic Labour MP Kate Hoey, who is backing Vote Leave, said: “We must end the supremacy of EU law over UK law.
“If we vote to leave, then the £350million we send to Brussels every week can be spent on our priorities like the NHS.
“I want to see a campaign which brings together those from all parts of the UK who want to take back control of our countries’ laws to the British Parliament.”
The new campaign features Labour MPs including Ms Hoey and Graham Stringer, former Tory Cabinet Minister Owen Paterson and UKIP’s sole MP Douglas Carswell.
It is bankrolled by a string of millionaire party donors, including Labour money-man John Mills, former Tory co-treasurer Peter Cruddas and spread-betting tycoon Stuart Wheeler, who has pumped a fortune into UKIP.
Mr Mills, who gave Labour £1.65million under Ed Miliband, said: “If we vote to leave the EU we will be able to trade freely with the EU and have friendly cooperation.
REUTERS UKIP's sole MP Douglas Carswell is also backing the Vote Leave campaign
“The UK will regain legal control of things like trade, tax, economic regulation and energy.
“We will be able to vote for people who will be able to make our own trade deals and control our own public services.”
Vote Leave’s website goes live tonight with its central message claiming EU institutions cannot cope with the huge pace of change in technology and economics.
It says Britain has “lost control of vital policies”, which is damaging to the UK.
The group will apply to the elections watchdog to become the official “out” campaign - giving it higher spending limits and taxpayers’ cash.
Conservatives for Britain co-chairman Steve Baker MP said: “We have established a great relationship with people across the political spectrum and we will work together to build the campaign we need in the interests of Britain and Europe.
“I personally support the Vote Leave campaign. I will be voting to leave unless, at the very least, the Prime Minister secures the end of the supremacy of EU law.”
UKIP MP Douglas Carswell said: “I look forward to building a campaign that has no interest in party loyalties and is focused on what is best for Britain and our friends in Europe.”
The In Campaign launches on Monday, and deputy director Lucy Thomas blasted the various pro-Brexit campaigners, saying they "have spent all summer fighting".
She added: "They can’t even bear to be in the same room as each other, let alone agree what life outside Europe would really look like for Britain.
“They cannot guarantee that British jobs would be safe outside Europe, or that prices wouldn’t rise. They have no idea whether we would retain our access to the world’s largest market, or how long it would take us to renegotiate free trade deals with over 50 countries around the globe.
“During this referendum campaign we will make the case that staying in Europe makes us stronger, while leaving would be a leap into the dark and a risk we can’t afford to take. We’re looking forward to setting out that case in the coming days.”
